bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Ronald Ross, August 9, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas reports on conditions in Panama regarding yellow fever and malaria. He recommends that the Nobel Prize be given to America.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Ronald Ross, August 9, 1905
div1.opener:
C O P Y .
August 9, 1905.
Dr. Ronald Ross,
Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine,
Liverpool, England.
Dear Doctor Ross:
div1.p:
Our monthly reports have given you some idea of how sani-
tary matters have been progressing at Panama since you left. The re-
sults of the mosquito work I think have been all that we could have desired.
Yellow fever has been done away with. Since December, 1905, we have had
only one case on the Isthmus, and in the old “hot bed,” the city of Panama,
not a single case since last November.

While we have had a good deal of malaria, the amount is not large.
For the months of April, May and June, among the whites we averaged one death
per month from this cause. Our force of whites is in the neighborhood
of 5,000. Among the negroes for the same time we have averaged eight
death from this cause; our force being about 23,000. June, July and August,
being the middle of the rainy season, are of course our heaviest malaria
months, but the total daily sick rate is very small, running from 15 per
thousand in April to 50 per thousand in July. Fifty per thousand is about
what our Army averaged last year, and I think is a most excellent showing for
a force in Panama, and I think every year the conditions as far as malaria
areis concerned will improve.

You recollect that when you were here you spoke to me about certain
letters which I was to write you, concerning Dr. Finley and Dr. Carter, and
-2-
their relation to the discovery of the part the mosquito plays in yellow fever.
You thought at the time that you would propose them for the Nobel Prize. I
merely mention it to remind you. It seems to me that the prize might very
well be given to America in this connection and that Carroll and Agramonte,
the two living members of the Board, might very well be included. It would
somewhat balance the fact that it had been given to Sanarelli for his work
which has turned out since to have no little foundation in fact.

This work, it seems to me, is way and beyond in importance many of
the subjects that have received prizes in the last few years. In fact the
only original research work whose practical results at all compare with it, is
your work with regard to the mosquito and malaria.

I wish you could come down again and see how we have progressed
since you were here. We are very much more comfortably fixed and could take
very much better care of you than we did last time.

closer.salute:
With kindest regards, I remain,
Yours very sincerely,
